title: Apply Technician MOM 58→61 to fix persistent weakness
description:
Technician is the persistent weakest archetype at 43-47% across all tiers and variants. Balance-tuner documented root cause (MOM=58 + STA=55 + shift paradox) and recommended MOM 58→61 (+3). Projected +2-3pp across tiers.

Change: In src/engine/archetypes.ts, update technician momentum from 58 to 61.

After applying, run `npx tsx src/tools/simulate.ts bare` and `npx tsx src/tools/simulate.ts giga` to verify win rate improvement. Target: Technician ≥47% at bare, ≥48% at giga.

Test cascade estimate: calculator.test.ts worked examples referencing Technician MOM (line ~414: MOM 63→66 with rarity bonus), match.test.ts worked example impact values. ~5-8 assertions will need updating by QA.

Acceptance criteria: Technician MOM=61 in archetypes.ts. Sim shows +2-3pp improvement. Failing test count documented for QA.

title: Fix test assertions broken by Technician MOM 58→61
description:
After BL-031 applies Technician MOM 58→61, multiple test assertions will break. Based on previous MOM change cascade (BL-014, MOM 55→58 broke 7 tests):

Expected breakage areas:
1. calculator.test.ts: Technician MOM in worked examples (e.g., line ~414 with uncommon rarity: MOM 63→66). Impact score calculations will change.
2. match.test.ts: Worked example Charger vs Technician — Technician effective stats change, impact values change, potentially outcome changes.
3. Possibly gear-variants.test.ts BL-004 deterministic cycling tests (fragile to ANY stat change).

Process:
1. Run `npx vitest run` to identify ALL failing assertions
2. Recalculate correct values for each broken assertion
3. Update test assertions to match new correct values
4. Verify ~699+ tests passing after fixes

DEPENDS ON: BL-031 (must be applied first).

Acceptance criteria: All tests passing. Test count ≥~699. No regressions.

title: Post-Technician-change full tier sweep and validation
description:
After BL-031 (Technician MOM +3) and BL-033 (test fixes) are complete, run a full simulation sweep to validate the change.

Run simulations at: bare, uncommon, rare, epic, giga (all 5 key tiers).
Also run uncommon aggressive, uncommon defensive for variant check.

Verify:
1. Technician win rate improved +2-3pp across tiers (target ≥47% bare, ≥48% giga)
2. No new dominance flags (no archetype >57% at any tier)
3. No new weakness flags (no archetype <40% at any tier)
4. Spread at each tier not worse than previous session
5. Charger and Bulwark win rates not significantly changed

DEPENDS ON: BL-031, BL-033 (tests must be passing first).

Acceptance criteria: Full sweep documented in analysis/balance-tuner-round-1.md. All flags resolved or accepted.

title: Migrate top-priority inline styles to CSS classes
description:
The CSS artist has created class replacements for ~50 inline style occurrences across 10 components. Start with the highest-impact migrations:

1. MatchSummary.tsx:87,92,132,134 — replace color inline styles with .text-p1/.text-p2 classes
2. PassResult.tsx:51,54,65,68 — replace marginTop inline styles with .mt-4 class
3. SetupScreen.tsx:42 — replace inline style with .difficulty-selector class
4. MatchSummary.tsx:229-256 — replace 6 inline styles with .loadout-mini* classes
5. LoadoutScreen.tsx:374 — replace fontSize/color inline with .text-small class

The CSS classes already exist in App.css. Just swap the JSX from style={{...}} to className='...'. Run tests after each file to catch regressions.

Acceptance criteria: At least 15 inline styles migrated. All tests passing (~699).

title: Improve combat result readability in PassResult
description:
PassResult.tsx shows joust pass outcomes but could communicate 'who won and why' more clearly. Improvements:

1. Add a clear winner indicator at the top of each pass result (e.g., 'Player 1 wins this pass!' or 'Draw!')
2. Highlight the winning score in bold or with a color accent
3. Show the impact score difference prominently (not buried in stats)
4. Make counter results more visible when they occur (counters are a key mechanic players need to learn)

Do NOT change engine logic — only presentation. Use existing CSS classes from App.css where available.

Acceptance criteria: Pass results clearly communicate winner at a glance. Tests passing.

title: Add rarity-colored borders to gear items in LoadoutScreen
description:
CSS artist (BL-024) added .gear-item--uncommon through .gear-item--giga CSS rules to App.css. These are dormant until the JSX adds the rarity class.

In LoadoutScreen.tsx, find all .gear-item elements and add the rarity-specific class:
- className should include `gear-item--${rarity}` where rarity comes from the gear piece or the loadout's rarity setting
- The CSS rules handle the border colors per tier

Acceptance criteria: Gear items display rarity-colored borders. Tests passing (~699).

title: Player experience audit — archetype identity and fun factor
description:
Play through (mentally simulate) several matches as each of the 6 archetypes. For each, assess:

1. Does this archetype have a clear IDENTITY that a player can feel? (Charger = momentum/aggression, Bulwark = defense/endurance, etc.)
2. Does their playstyle create interesting DECISIONS? Or do you just pick the same attack every time?
3. Is there a 'power fantasy' moment? (Charger landing a devastating lance charge, Technician outmaneuvering with precision)
4. Which archetype is the LEAST fun to play, even if balanced? Why?
5. What ONE mechanic change would make the weakest archetype more enjoyable?

Read src/engine/archetypes.ts, src/engine/attacks.ts, and recent balance data. Write your analysis to orchestrator/analysis/design-round-1.md.

Acceptance criteria: Detailed fun-factor assessment for all 6 archetypes with at least 2 actionable proposals.

title: Evaluate gear variant impact on player decisions
description:
Analyze whether the 3 gear variants (aggressive/balanced/defensive) create meaningful player choices:

1. Does variant choice feel impactful or like noise? Can a player FEEL the difference between all-aggressive and all-defensive loadouts?
2. Are there interesting variant combinations? (e.g., aggressive lance + defensive armor for a specific matchup strategy)
3. Is the UI clear enough for players to understand what each variant does?
4. Should variant choice interact with archetype selection? (e.g., aggressive gear on a Bulwark — is that a fun contrarian build or just suboptimal?)
5. Propose any improvements to make variant selection more engaging.

Read src/engine/gigling-gear.ts, src/engine/player-gear.ts, and the gear variant test data. Write analysis to orchestrator/analysis/design-round-2.md.

Acceptance criteria: Clear assessment of variant system with at least 1 concrete improvement proposal.

title: New player experience — first-match clarity audit
description:
Imagine a player who has NEVER played this game opening it for the first time. Walk through their experience:

1. Setup screen: Do they understand what archetypes mean? Are stat labels (MOM/CTL/GRD/INIT/STA) clear?
2. Loadout screen: Is gear/rarity/variant selection overwhelming? What could be simplified for first-timers?
3. Speed selection: Do they understand the speed/power tradeoff?
4. Attack selection: Can they learn the counter system? Are hints sufficient?
5. Pass results: Can they understand what happened and WHY they won/lost?
6. Melee phase: Is the transition clear? Do they understand the new attack set?

Propose improvements focused on CLARITY, not dumbing down. The depth should be there for experienced players but the surface should be approachable.

Write analysis to orchestrator/analysis/design-round-3.md.

Acceptance criteria: Walkthrough of first-match experience with at least 3 clarity improvement proposals ranked by impact.
